title: Getting Started with CSS: Simple Styling for Your Web Pages

content.text: CSS stands for Cascading Style Sheets. It is a language used to style and layout web pages. With CSS, you can change colors, fonts, spacing, and even the layout of your web pages. While HTML creates the structure, CSS is responsible for how it looks. This makes it easy to separate content from design.
content.additional_text: In this example, we set the background color of the entire page to white and use the Arial font for the text. You can change these values to customize the look of your website.

content.text: CSS allows you to select HTML elements to apply styles. You can use different types of selectors, such as element selectors (like `h1`), class selectors (like `.highlight`), and ID selectors (like `#header`). This flexibility helps you style multiple elements efficiently.

content.text: Every element on a web page can be thought of as a box. The CSS box model consists of the content area, padding, border, and margin. Understanding this model helps you manage the spacing and layout of elements on your page.
content.additional_text: This code styles a `<div>` element with a margin of 15 pixels outside the border, 10 pixels of padding inside the border, and a 1-pixel solid black border. This creates space around the box, inside the box, and a visible border.

content.text: Responsive design ensures your website looks good on any device, like a computer or a smartphone. CSS media queries allow you to apply styles based on the screen size. This helps your website adjust its layout to fit different screens.
content.additional_text: In this example, when the screen width is 500 pixels or less, the body background changes to light blue, and all `<h1>` elements will have a font size of 20 pixels. This makes your website more user-friendly on smaller devices.
